node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 24, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says 'How a techr ology revolution powered th Taliban's return'.

node.text:
When the Taliban was last in control of Afghanistan, the world used cellphones for voice calls, the Internet was accessed from desktop computers over copper phone lines, and digital photography was in its infancy.

The Taliban originally fought to the top of Afghanistan’s power struggles in 1996, advocating a return to the 7th century, when Islam was founded. It envisioned a nation of self-sufficient peasant farmers, ruled under Shariah, and rejected any need for modern technology.

But within a few years of defeat by the U.S. military in 2001, the militant Islamists were deploying makeshift surveillance drones and coordinating their political and operational messaging through a network of mobile handsets. "The decision to embrace, rather than reject, the trappings of the 21st century went on to become a key to the movement’s survival and eventual retaking of Kabul," explains Tim Culpan.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#afghanistan

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Luxury might be about to its most important customer Chinese consumers' share of global luxury spending American 50% 40 30 20 10 2010 '11 '12 '13 '14 '15 '16 Source:Jefferies '17 '18 19 '20 '21 '22 '23 '24 2025 BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
What happens if revenge spending in China crashes to a halt? Luxury giants don't want to find out.

The past few weeks have brought some concerning signals from China: Covid-19 cases are rising, retail sales are slowing and a government crackdown on certain growth sectors and comments from President Xi Jinping about the need for “common prosperity” raise the possibility of curbs on overt shows of wealth. 

Chinese consumers are the number one driver of global sales of top-end goods. If demand from the country’s big spenders starts to evaporate, that would have dire consequences for the luxury houses, writes Anjani Trivedi and Andrea Felsted. 

Click the link in our bio to read the full column.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We Wejust took a step closer to harnessing a source of almost unlimited clean energy BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
It sounds thoroughly implausible: a technology that could replicate the chemistry of the stars, unleash nearly unlimited clean energy and safely power the world for centuries.

Yet sustainable nuclear fusion, long hypothesized, took a step closer to reality this month.

Scientists at the National Ignition Facility, part of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, announced that they had produced about 10 quadrillion watts of fusion power after blasting a hydrogen capsule with an array of laser beams. The burst lasted only a fraction of a second. But it offered significant new evidence that harnessing fusion energy could one day be feasible.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about why this is a cause for climate optimism.

#nuclearfusion #fusion #cleanenergy #hydrogen #science #climatechange

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Huge gains in female education risk being erased in Afghanistan Literacy rate for 15-24 year old females Female adults 60% 40 20 1979 1990 Source: World Bank 2000 2010 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🇦🇫The story in Afghanistan for the last two decades has been a positive one for women and girls. Now, with the Taliban back in charge, that progress risks disappearing completely.

As of 2019, over 9 million children were in education, 39% of them girls. The last decade or so has seen the first cohorts of female medical students in modern-day Afghanistan graduate, an Afghan Girls’ robotics team and more women enrolling at universities. As more girls have been in education, literacy rates have soared.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how life in Afghanistan has changed for women in recent years, and what the return of Sharia law might mean for them now.

#afghanistan #womensrights #equality

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '$500 million spacesuit? Welcome to NASA Acontracting. BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
What’s the cost of a good suit these days? At NASA, apparently, it’s about $500 million. That’s according to a new audit of the space agency’s 14-year quest to design and build a new generation of spacesuits.

Without major changes to the program, the new duds will take at least four more years to produce, thereby jeopardizing NASA’s plan to return to the moon by 2024.

"Just a few years ago, there might’ve been no way to feasibly accelerate that timeline. But thanks to the growth of the thriving U.S. commercial-space industry, NASA now has options beyond the traditional contractors who’ve long helped it build space hardware in-house," writes Adam Minter.

With the clock ticking, will the agency be able to get the job done — and get the moon mission back on track? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

#space #nasa #spacesuit #design #moon

node.text:
📨There’s not much middle ground in the email wars.

On one side are the “inbox zero” partisans, who argue that every email must be dealt with. At the other end is “inbox infinity” — an acceptance of the reality that most of us will never catch up.

Despite a variety of filters to discard spam automatically, some people’s unread messages run into the six figures, writes Stephen Carter.

If you’re in that camp, don’t despair — you’re in good company: Even Merlin Mann, who coined the term “inbox zero,” admits that his own is “embarrassingly cluttered."

In business, the problem is ubiquitous. Professionals live in secret terror of missing urgent emails from clients or bosses, which helps explain the widespread adoption of alternatives. But the issue arises everywhere.

Tap the link in our bio to read some of the working world's most embarrassing stories about the consequences of missed emails.

#email #inboxzero #inboxinfinity #emailwars

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '50 years after going off gold, the dollar must go for crypto BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
💵In August of 1971, President Richard Nixon announced that the link between the U.S. dollar and gold was to be severed.

For foreign leaders, finance ministers and central bankers, this was stunning. Not only would the U.S. dollar cease to be convertible into gold; the U.S. was apparently turning away from the free trade it had embraced at the end of World War II.

But “the Nixon shock” did not mark the end of the era of dollar dominance. On the contrary, the U.S. currency has only grown more important.

There's a lesson here for every commentator who is tempted to speculate about the dollar’s demise, writes Niall Ferguson. The past 18 months have sped up both innovation in decentralized finance and adoption by a wider range of investors and institutions of established cryptocurrencies.

If we have learned nothing else from the past half-century, it is surely that the best way to win a race with totalitarian rivals is not to copy them, but to out-innovate them. Tap the link in our bio to read about how crypto might end up being a much bigger bonanza than we expect it to be.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Would you quit your job and freelance in order to work at home? Would you consider becoming a freelancer/self-employed in order to continue to work remotely? "Yes" answers. Men Women 30% 20 10 to 25to34 35t 45to54 Û Google Consumer Source:Upwork Upwork 55to64 Total BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
After spending more time with their children than any generation of fathers in living memory, the pandemic experience is resulting a different outlook on their working life.

Using a survey of 18 to 64 year olds who worked remotely at least half the time during the pandemic, Upwork economist Adam Ozimek reported that 18% of people said they would consider becoming a freelancer or self-employed in order to continue working remotely.

Looking at the responses by age and gender, the group with the highest share of people saying they would consider it were men between the ages of 35-44, the cohort of people most likely to have children under the age of 18.

"As a work-from-home father of children aged 5 and 3 with a wife working in medicine, I can attest to the difficulty of scheduling daily childcare drop-off, pick-up, dinnertime, bathtime and bedtime, and how it wouldn't be workable if both of us had office jobs that stretched from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., with a commute on both ends," writes Conor Sen.

Tap the link in our bio to read his column in full.

#father #wfh #remote #jobs #freelance

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 21, 2021. May be an image of cake and text that says 'Four financial goals that you should achieve before turning 40 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
With so much advice catering to young adults and retirees, the 40-somethings can seem like the forgotten generation.

By the time you turn 40, you're less likely to be grappling with as much student loan debt as a 25-year-old and not yet navigating through the maze of Medicare. But your 40s are prime time for focusing on your financial health, by righting some wrongs made in the earlier years and capitalizing on what can be peak earning years, writes Farnoosh Torabi.

Torabi's financial goals for people in their 40s are simple:

1. Know your worth — and add 50%.
2. Pretend your 30-year mortgage ends in 20.
3. Invest in alternatives.

Tap the link in our bio to read the fourth and final goal.

#goals #finance #wealth #40 #birthday #planning

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Almost twice as many Germans as Brits are hitting the beaches TUI passenger capacity July 2021 300K 200 100 Germany Source: TUI Belgium U.K Netherlands BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🏖If you open it, they will vacation.

At least, that's the theory. Unfortunately, Covid is still holding back holidays somewhat.

Demand from the U.K. for overseas travel has been held back by the government’s inconsistent travel advice, which was creating uncertainty for consumers. That includes the high cost of testing, explains @andrea_felsted. While sales have picked up over the past two weeks, Brits cancelled more holidays for most of this year than they booked. That’s in stark contrast to Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands, where sales mostly exceeded cancellations.

The delta variant of the coronavirus, too, appears to be putting people off going on vacation. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#vacation #holiday #summer

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 20, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Warren Buffett's electric car bet isn'tsexy, but it'sreliable BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The value of Berkshire Hathaway’s holdings in BYD, one of China’s oldest makers of cars and automotive batteries, has skyrocketed this year: BYD’s share price is up almost 30%.

Warren Buffett gets lots of investments right with his patient and deliberate buy-and-hold strategy. He’s doing it again with electric vehicles.

Anjani Trivedi writes: "For investors pouring money into the technology, it would be wise to consider how the Sage of Omaha has looked into the future of the sector... Buffett has backed BYD for over a decade, holding around 22%, which now sits on a market capitalization of over $117.6 billion. That’s more than investor darling Nio Inc., the new-generation Chinese automaker listed in New York."

So how is that different from the rest of the EV universe, which just keeps on surging? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#warrenbuffett #ev #electricvehicles #investment

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of text that says 'Percentage change in bankers earning Brexit is pushing high-earning bankers to quit the U.K. million euros or more between 2018 and 2019 20% 15 10 U.K. Italy Source:European Banking Authority France Germany BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
🇬🇧Brexit boosted one U.K. export: millionaire British bankers.

"This is one outflow that the country can ill afford, given the nation’s dependence on the finance industry for almost 7% of total economic output," writes Mark Gilbert.

Figures just released by the European Banking Authority show that the number of U.K. bankers earning 1 million euros ($1.2 million) or more a year shrank in 2019 as the nation prepared to exit the EU after the 2016 referendum on Brexit.

High-earning financiers have been abandoning London and moving to Frankfurt, Paris and Milan. Tap the link in our bio to find out why that's worrisome for the U.K. financial capital.

#brexit #banker #london #finance #uk #eu
